trans-unit.source: Specifies how distributed transactions interact with COM+ transactions.
The .NET Framework allows managed .NET components to participate in COM+ transactions using the classes in the <xref:System.EnterpriseServices> namespace.
However, since the interoperation is not provided by default, you need to use this enumeration to specify how you want to participate in the COM+ context.
Specifically, when you create a new <xref:System.Transactions.TransactionScope>, use this enumeration to indicate how you want your transaction to participate in COM+ transactions.
For more information, see [Interoperability with Enterprise Services and COM+ Transactions](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/2e93b3c6-4d48-4b9b-82b2-7d5908a2c970).
Search for an existing COM+ context and synchronize with it if one exists.

The <xref href="System.EnterpriseServices"></xref> context (which can be retrieved by calling the static method <xref href="System.EnterpriseServices.ContextUtil.Transaction"></xref> of the <xref href="System.EnterpriseServices.ContextUtil"></xref> class) and the <xref href="System.Transactions"></xref> ambient transaction (which can be retrieved by calling the static method <xref href="System.Transactions.Transaction.Current"></xref> of the <xref href="System.Transactions.Transaction"></xref> class) are always synchronized.
This introduces a performance penalty because new <xref href="System.EnterpriseServices"></xref> contexts may need to be created.
There is no synchronization between <xref href="System.EnterpriseServices.ContextUtil.Transaction"></xref> and <xref href="System.Transactions.Transaction.Current"></xref>.
